page.title: 19WEST LANE,SUTTON
page.content: West Lane leads from High St.up onto Sutton and Cowling Moors.At the bottom of the lane are two cottages dated 1638,with drip stones above mullioned windows.To the left is the entrance to Sutton Hall,built in 1894 by a local mill-owner J.W.Hartley,for Â£40,000 in the Victorian-Gothic style.It was demolished in the 1940's. Further up West Lane is the site of the Pinfold. This was a circular stone structure, 6ft high and 10yds in diameter.The Pinder in the late 19th century was Peter Petty,who while rounding up stray animals was also the local mole catcher.The Pinfold was demolished in 1896. Beyond the Pinfold is Stubbing Hill, meaning "clearing on the hill".21 people lived on the farm in 1851 but fire destroyed it in 1886.
